passage_text:
Birds
    
    
        Hello! It's Rattenborough again! You have learned about many animal groups. You know about mammals, reptiles, fish, and amphibians. Do you remember their different traits? Fish are the largest group of animals with backbones. Today we will talk about the second largest groupbirds.
Birds belong to their own special group. Birds are very adaptive, which means they can live in many different places. You can find birds in hot deserts and in the coldest places on Earth. Many birds love forests. Some birds live near the ocean. If you go out on a boat near land, you might see sea birds like seagulls flying around.

---

Like mammals, birds are warm-blooded. Many birds move to new places when seasons change. In late fall, they fly together in groups called flocks. They fly from cold places to warm places. Then in spring, they fly back home again. Birds are the only animals that can fly like airplanes, except for some insects and bats.
All birds have wings, but not all birds can fly. Penguins are well-known birds that cannot fly. But penguins are amazing swimmers instead! Ostriches are the biggest birds of all. They cannot fly either, but they can run very fast. They also lay the world's largest eggs.
All birds have two legs and a mouth called a beak. Birds do not have teeth. The most important thing about birds is that they all have feathers. Feathers help birds fly and stay warm. Bird feathers come in many colors and sizes. A bird's feathers are also called plumage. Peacocks have the most beautiful plumage of all birds. They like to show off by spreading their long, colorful feathers.

---

Most birds build nests for their homes. Many birds make their own nests high up in trees or thick bushes. They use pieces from nature like twigs and plant parts to build their nests. Other birds make nests inside tree holes. Some bird nests are made of mud.
Most birds lay eggs in their nests. Some birds lay many eggs and some lay only one or two. The nest must be safe to protect the eggs from bad weather and other animals. Birds sit on their eggs to keep them warm until they hatch. When baby birds are born, they need lots of food. Mother and father birds fly out to find food. They bring it back and put the food right into each baby's beak.

---

Many birds eat both plants and animals. Some birds eat seeds and berries. Some eat insects. Great blue herons eat fish. Hawks eat small mammals. Tiny hummingbirds eat sweet nectar from flowers. All birds need to drink water too.
Birds are famous for their beautiful songs. They sing to attract other birds and to mark their territory. Sometimes birds seem to sing just because they are happy. Maybe they sing to remind us how wonderful and amazing the animal kingdom really is!

option_2_explanation: You got it! The passage says nests protect eggs from 'bad weather and other animals.' You found the right connection!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't talk about making parents comfortable. It focuses on keeping the eggs safe from danger.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story talks about protecting eggs before they hatch. It doesn't mention babies leaving the nest.

specificity_check: all describe purposes or benefits of safe nests

passage_text:
Birds
    
    
        Hello! It's Rattenborough again! You have learned about many animal groups. You know about mammals, reptiles, fish, and amphibians. Do you remember their different traits? Fish are the largest group of animals with backbones. Today we will talk about the second largest groupbirds.
Birds belong to their own special group. Birds are very adaptive, which means they can live in many different places. You can find birds in hot deserts and in the coldest places on Earth. Many birds love forests. Some birds live near the ocean. If you go out on a boat near land, you might see sea birds like seagulls flying around.

---

Like mammals, birds are warm-blooded. Many birds move to new places when seasons change. In late fall, they fly together in groups called flocks. They fly from cold places to warm places. Then in spring, they fly back home again. Birds are the only animals that can fly like airplanes, except for some insects and bats.
All birds have wings, but not all birds can fly. Penguins are well-known birds that cannot fly. But penguins are amazing swimmers instead! Ostriches are the biggest birds of all. They cannot fly either, but they can run very fast. They also lay the world's largest eggs.
All birds have two legs and a mouth called a beak. Birds do not have teeth. The most important thing about birds is that they all have feathers. Feathers help birds fly and stay warm. Bird feathers come in many colors and sizes. A bird's feathers are also called plumage. Peacocks have the most beautiful plumage of all birds. They like to show off by spreading their long, colorful feathers.

---

Most birds build nests for their homes. Many birds make their own nests high up in trees or thick bushes. They use pieces from nature like twigs and plant parts to build their nests. Other birds make nests inside tree holes. Some bird nests are made of mud.
Most birds lay eggs in their nests. Some birds lay many eggs and some lay only one or two. The nest must be safe to protect the eggs from bad weather and other animals. Birds sit on their eggs to keep them warm until they hatch. When baby birds are born, they need lots of food. Mother and father birds fly out to find food. They bring it back and put the food right into each baby's beak.

---

Many birds eat both plants and animals. Some birds eat seeds and berries. Some eat insects. Great blue herons eat fish. Hawks eat small mammals. Tiny hummingbirds eat sweet nectar from flowers. All birds need to drink water too.
Birds are famous for their beautiful songs. They sing to attract other birds and to mark their territory. Sometimes birds seem to sing just because they are happy. Maybe they sing to remind us how wonderful and amazing the animal kingdom really is!
question: What is the main idea of Section 3 of the passage?
option_1: Birds use different materials like twigs and mud to construct their nests.
option_2: Birds build nests, lay eggs, and care for their babies until they hatch.
option_3: Baby birds need their parents to bring them food after they are born.
option_4: Bird nests must be kept safe from bad weather and other animals.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story does talk about nest materials, but that's just one small part. The whole section is about much more than just building nests.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The section talks about how "birds build nests" and lay eggs and care for babies. It covers the whole process from start to finish!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but feeding babies is only mentioned at the very end. The section starts with building nests and talks about the whole process of raising babies.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Keeping nests safe is mentioned, but it's just one detail. The section is really about the whole process of having baby birds.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3/paragraph 5 comprehensive main idea about nesting cycle - differs from reference which asks about Section 2 purpose
homogeneity_check: all choices are summary statements about Section 3 content
specificity_check: all provide potential main ideas at varying breadth
length_check: option_1: 11 words, option_2: 14 words, option_3: 13 words, option_4: 12 words (balanced within 10%)
semantic_distance_check: distinct scopes: materials only vs. full cycle vs. feeding only vs. safety only
single_correct_check: only B encompasses all major details in the section
diversity_check: targets Section 3 nesting cycle - completely different section than reference about Section 2 and different focus than previous variant

passage_text:
Mammals
    
    
        Hello! I am Rattenborough, and I want to tell you about my favorite animal group - mammals! I am a mammal myself. Do you know what makes an animal a mammal? Mammals have hair on their bodies. They give birth to live babies and feed milk to their young. Mammals breathe air with their lungs. They are also warm-blooded and have backbones.
Most scientists think mammals are the smartest animals on Earth. All animals communicate in different ways. Dogs bark and wag their tails to talk. Cows make mooing sounds. Cats can meow or roar. But mammals use the most complex ways to talk to each other. Humans use language to speak with words. They also use their faces and hands to share ideas. Some apes and chimpanzees have learned sign language to talk with their hands.

---

Two amazing mammals live in the ocean. You might not know that dolphins and whales are mammals because they swim like fish. But these ocean mammals cannot breathe underwater like fish do. Fish have gills, but dolphins and whales have blowholes on top of their heads. They swim to the surface and poke their heads up to breathe air.
Whales and dolphins have a special way to find things in the dark ocean water. They send out sound waves called sonar. These sound waves travel through the water and hit objects. Then the sounds bounce back as an echo. When the whale or dolphin hears the echo come back, it can tell how big something is and how far away it is. They also use these sounds to talk to each other! Like all mammals, dolphins and whales give birth to live babies and feed them milk. They have hair and thick skin that keeps them warm and safe from animals that want to eat them called predators.

---

Another surprising mammal is the bat. Bats can fly like birds, but they are not birds at all. Bats have fur instead of feathers. Their wings are made of skin flaps, not feathers like bird wings. Bats give birth to live babies and make milk for them. This is why scientists say bats are mammals, not birds.
Here is a very interesting fact about mammals. Almost all mammals give birth to live babies. But two special mammals lay eggs! The duck-billed platypus and the spiny anteater lay eggs like birds do. But they still have hair, make milk, and have all the other things that make them mammals. These strange creatures are very hard to find because they are so rare!

---

Mammals come in many different shapes and sizes. Some swim in oceans, some fly in the sky, and some walk on land. But all mammals share the same basic things - they have hair, backbones, make milk for their babies, and are warm-blooded. These characteristics help scientists know that an animal is a mammal, no matter how different it might look!
question: What is the purpose of this passage?
option_1: to explain what makes an animal a mammal
option_2: to compare mammals to fish and birds
option_3: to teach readers how to take care of pet mammals
option_4: to tell stories about ocean animals
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea by seeing that the story asks "Do you know what makes an animal a mammal?" The whole passage explains mammal traits like hair, milk, and breathing air.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story mentions fish, but only to show that whales and dolphins are still mammals. The main purpose is to explain what makes animals mammals, not to compare different animal groups.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't teach pet care! It asks "Do you know what makes an animal a mammal?" and explains mammal traits like having hair and making milk for babies.
option_4_explanation: Close! The ocean animals are just examples to show mammal traits. The whole story is about explaining what makes an animal a mammal, not telling ocean stories.

passage_text:
Mammals
    
    
        Hello! I am Rattenborough, and I want to tell you about my favorite animal group - mammals! I am a mammal myself. Do you know what makes an animal a mammal? Mammals have hair on their bodies. They give birth to live babies and feed milk to their young. Mammals breathe air with their lungs. They are also warm-blooded and have backbones.
Most scientists think mammals are the smartest animals on Earth. All animals communicate in different ways. Dogs bark and wag their tails to talk. Cows make mooing sounds. Cats can meow or roar. But mammals use the most complex ways to talk to each other. Humans use language to speak with words. They also use their faces and hands to share ideas. Some apes and chimpanzees have learned sign language to talk with their hands.

---

Two amazing mammals live in the ocean. You might not know that dolphins and whales are mammals because they swim like fish. But these ocean mammals cannot breathe underwater like fish do. Fish have gills, but dolphins and whales have blowholes on top of their heads. They swim to the surface and poke their heads up to breathe air.
Whales and dolphins have a special way to find things in the dark ocean water. They send out sound waves called sonar. These sound waves travel through the water and hit objects. Then the sounds bounce back as an echo. When the whale or dolphin hears the echo come back, it can tell how big something is and how far away it is. They also use these sounds to talk to each other! Like all mammals, dolphins and whales give birth to live babies and feed them milk. They have hair and thick skin that keeps them warm and safe from animals that want to eat them called predators.

---

Another surprising mammal is the bat. Bats can fly like birds, but they are not birds at all. Bats have fur instead of feathers. Their wings are made of skin flaps, not feathers like bird wings. Bats give birth to live babies and make milk for them. This is why scientists say bats are mammals, not birds.
Here is a very interesting fact about mammals. Almost all mammals give birth to live babies. But two special mammals lay eggs! The duck-billed platypus and the spiny anteater lay eggs like birds do. But they still have hair, make milk, and have all the other things that make them mammals. These strange creatures are very hard to find because they are so rare!

---

Mammals come in many different shapes and sizes. Some swim in oceans, some fly in the sky, and some walk on land. But all mammals share the same basic things - they have hair, backbones, make milk for their babies, and are warm-blooded. These characteristics help scientists know that an animal is a mammal, no matter how different it might look!
question: The author describes bats, whales, and the platypus in sections 2-4. How does this structure help explain the author's main point?
option_1: It proves that only unusual animals should be considered mammals
option_2: It demonstrates that mammals must all look and act the same way
option_3: It shows variety while emphasizing that key characteristics remain constant
option_4: It argues that scientists cannot agree on what makes a mammal
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story talks about unusual mammals like whales and bats, but it also mentions regular ones like dogs and cats. All mammals count, not just the weird ones!
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The examples show mammals are very different - some swim, some fly, some lay eggs. They don't look or act the same at all.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story shows different mammals but they all have the same basic things like "hair, make milk, breathe air." Different looks, same important parts!
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says what "scientists say" about mammals like it's true facts. There's no fighting or disagreeing mentioned anywhere.

passage_text:
Scientists Who Classify Animals
    
    
        Hello, Rattenborough here again! You have been learning about how scientists study living things. Scientists put all living things into five big groups called kingdoms. You have learned how animals are sorted into smaller groups within the animal kingdom.
The scientists who study animals are called zoologists. Zoologists observe animals to see how they are the same and different. To observe means to watch carefully and learn. For example, zoologists found out that some animals are warm-blooded and some are cold-blooded.
Zoologists also group animals by whether they have a backbone or not. Animals with a backbone are called vertebrates. Animals without a backbone are called invertebrates. There are five groups of vertebrates. These groups are fish, birds, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals. Fish make up the largest group of vertebrates.

---

Zoologists study other parts of animals too. They study animal body parts and how they are alike or different. All animals need to breathe oxygen. But they have different body parts called organs that help them breathe. An organ is a body part that does a special job. Fish and young amphibians have gills. Gills are organs that help them get oxygen from water. Mammals, reptiles, and adult amphibians use lungs. Lungs are organs that get oxygen from air.
Zoologists also study how animal babies are born and cared for. Do you remember which group of animal mothers feed their babies milk from their own bodies? That's right - mammals!

---

A Greek man named Aristotle first grouped animals over 2,000 years ago. Aristotle wrote a book called A History of Animals. As scientists learned more about animals, they changed how animals are grouped. There is still much to learn about animals. After all, there are thousands of new animals that scientists have not found yet!
Every day, scientists learn new facts about animals. Scientists even find new animals they didn't know exist. To exist means to be real or to live somewhere. There is always new knowledge to discover when you study living things! Knowledge means facts and information that we learn.

---

Today, there are about one million scientists around the world studying animals. Every one of them spends their day watching, testing, and finding new information. This adds to our knowledge about the world we live in.
If you want to be a zoologist when you grow up, there is plenty to study. You never know when someone will learn something that changes how we think about the world. Who knows? Maybe you will be the first to find a feathered fish or a flying snail. It may sound silly now, but a hundred years ago, nobody knew that whales talked to each other. What will you discover?
question: What must happen first before scientists can discover new animals that don't exist in our knowledge yet?

option_2: Scientists must group all known animals into the five kingdoms.
option_3: Scientists must watch, test, and find new information in unexplored places.

option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but grouping known animals just organizes what we already know. Finding new animals means looking for ones we've never seen before.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says scientists must be "watching, testing, and finding new information." They have to explore and look carefully to discover new animals.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Aristotle's old book is about animals from long ago. The story doesn't say reading old books helps find new animals today.

option_2: explain that all the important animal discoveries have already been made.
option_3: encourage readers to think about contributing to future animal knowledge.
option_4: describe how scientists discover thousands of new animals every single day.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The question isn't about studying being hard. The story talks about exciting discoveries, not difficult work.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The story says there's "still much to learn about animals." It shows there's more to discover, not that everything is already found.
option_3_explanation: Exactly! The story says "Maybe you will be the first" to find new animals. The question wants kids to think about making their own discoveries!
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say thousands are found every day. The question is asking what YOU might discover someday!

passage_text:
Scientists Who Classify Animals
    
    
        Hello, Rattenborough here again! You have been learning about how scientists study living things. Scientists put all living things into five big groups called kingdoms. You have learned how animals are sorted into smaller groups within the animal kingdom.
The scientists who study animals are called zoologists. Zoologists observe animals to see how they are the same and different. To observe means to watch carefully and learn. For example, zoologists found out that some animals are warm-blooded and some are cold-blooded.
Zoologists also group animals by whether they have a backbone or not. Animals with a backbone are called vertebrates. Animals without a backbone are called invertebrates. There are five groups of vertebrates. These groups are fish, birds, amphibians, reptiles, and mammals. Fish make up the largest group of vertebrates.

---

Zoologists study other parts of animals too. They study animal body parts and how they are alike or different. All animals need to breathe oxygen. But they have different body parts called organs that help them breathe. An organ is a body part that does a special job. Fish and young amphibians have gills. Gills are organs that help them get oxygen from water. Mammals, reptiles, and adult amphibians use lungs. Lungs are organs that get oxygen from air.
Zoologists also study how animal babies are born and cared for. Do you remember which group of animal mothers feed their babies milk from their own bodies? That's right - mammals!

---

Everything we know about animals was discovered by scientists. Many scientists have been interested in animals for a very long time. A Greek man named Aristotle first grouped animals over 2,000 years ago. Aristotle wrote a book called A History of Animals. As scientists learned more about animals, they changed how animals are grouped. There is still much to learn about animals. After all, there are thousands of new animals that scientists have not found yet!
Every day, scientists learn new facts about animals. Scientists even find new animals they didn't know exist. To exist means to be real or to live somewhere. There is always new knowledge to discover when you study living things! Knowledge means facts and information that we learn.

---

Today, there are about one million scientists around the world studying animals. Every one of them spends their day watching, testing, and finding new information. This adds to our knowledge about the world we live in.
If you want to be a zoologist when you grow up, there is plenty to study. You never know when someone will learn something that changes how we think about the world. Who knows? Maybe you will be the first to find a feathered fish or a flying snail. It may sound silly now, but a hundred years ago, nobody knew that whales talked to each other. What will you discover?
question: Which statement best describes the main idea of the entire passage?
option_1: Aristotle was the first scientist to study and classify animals long ago.
option_2: Zoologists use different methods to study, classify, and discover animals.
option_3: There are five main groups of vertebrates that scientists have identified.
option_4: Scientists around the world spend every day making new animal discoveries.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't mention Aristotle at all. The story talks about many ways zoologists study animals today.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story shows how zoologists "observe animals" and group them in lots of different ways. It talks about all their methods for studying animals.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the five vertebrate groups are just one small part of the story. The whole story is about all the different ways zoologists study animals.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story mentions discoveries, but it's mostly about how zoologists classify and study animals in many ways. Discovery is just one part.
differentiation_notes: Requires synthesis of all paragraphs to identify overarching main idea about zoologist methods - differs from reference by focusing on methods rather than purpose of writing
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about content in the passage
specificity_check: all make claims about what the passage emphasizes
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 10 words, C: 10 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 9%
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms; each focuses on different aspect
single_correct_check: only B encompasses classification, study, and discovery across all paragraphs
diversity_check: requires synthesizing all paragraphs for main idea about methods - completely different from reference about author's purpose

passage_text:
Jane Goodall
    
    
        Jane Goodall is a very famous primatologist. A primatologist is a scientist who studies a group of animals called primates. Primates are mammals that include humans, monkeys, gorillas, and chimpanzees. Jane Goodall has spent her whole life studying chimpanzees. She watches their behavior, which means how they act and what they do each day. Her discoveries have made her one of the best known scientists in the world.
Goodall was born in 1934 in London, England. When she was a little girl, her father gave her a toy chimpanzee. It looked so real that people who visited her house were afraid of it, but she loved it! This toy helped her dream about studying real chimpanzees someday.

---

When Goodall was 23 years old, she went to Africa. She began studying chimpanzees with a well-known scientist named Louis Leakey. After a year of working in Africa, Goodall went back to England. She studied at the University of Cambridge. Can you guess what her favorite subject was? Chimpanzees!
After finishing school, Goodall returned to Africa. She spent the next 45 years studying chimpanzees in the wild. Her discoveries during those years completely changed the way people think about primates. Before Goodall's work, people thought chimpanzees were herbivores. An herbivore is an animal that only eats plants. She discovered that chimps also eat meat, making them omnivores. An omnivore is an animal that eats both plants and meat.

---

More importantly, Goodall discovered that chimps were very intelligent. Being intelligent means being smart and able to learn new things. She watched them making and using tools! Before that, people thought humans were the only animals that made and used tools. Goodall saw chimps using blades of grass and sticks as tools. Chimps like to eat termites, which are insects like ants. To catch these tasty insects, a chimp would stick a blade of grass into a termite hole. The termites would crawl onto the grass. Then, the chimp would pull out the grass and eat all the termites.
Goodall gave names to all the chimps she studied. She learned that chimps show many of the same feelings as people. They can feel happy, sad, and angry. This behavior helped people understand that chimps are very special animals.

---

Goodall is more than a scientist. She is also an activist. An activist is someone who works hard to solve problems and change things in the world. Goodall works to protect chimpanzees and their homes in the wild. She teaches others about human damage to animal homes. This damage includes hunting and pollution. Pollution happens when harmful things get into the air, water, or land where animals live.
She loves working with young people and teaching them how to protect animals. She has written many books and has won many awards for her work. Even when she was 79 years old, she was still working to spread the message that animals need our protection!
question: Someone might read this passage to
option_1: persuade others to protect animals.
option_2: learn facts about Jane Goodall.
option_3: enjoy a story about chimpanzees.
option_4: learn how to become a scientist.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The passage doesn't try to convince us to protect animals. It mostly tells us facts about Jane Goodall's life and work.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the right purpose by noticing facts like "Goodall was born in 1934." The passage teaches us about Jane Goodall's life.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but this isn't a fun story about chimps. The passage gives us real facts about Jane Goodall's life and discoveries.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The passage doesn't teach steps to become a scientist. It tells us facts about what Jane Goodall did in her life.

Chimps like to eat termites, which are insects like ants. To catch these tasty insects, a chimp would stick a blade of grass into a termite hole. The termites would crawl onto the grass. Then, the chimp would pull out the grass and eat all the termites.
Goodall gave names to all the chimps she studied. She learned that chimps show many of the same feelings as people. They can feel happy, sad, and angry. This behavior helped people understand that chimps are very special animals.

---

Goodall is more than a scientist. She is also an activist. An activist is someone who works hard to solve problems and change things in the world. Goodall works to protect chimpanzees and their homes in the wild. She teaches others about human damage to animal homes. This damage includes hunting and pollution. Pollution happens when harmful things get into the air, water, or land where animals live.
She loves working with young people and teaching them how to protect animals. She has written many books and has won many awards for her work. Even when she was 79 years old, she was still working to spread the message that animals need our protection!

passage_text:
Jane Goodall
    
    
        Jane Goodall is a very famous primatologist. A primatologist is a scientist who studies a group of animals called primates. ---

When Goodall was 23 years old, she went to Africa. She began studying chimpanzees with a well-known scientist named Louis Leakey. After a year of working in Africa, Goodall went back to England. She studied at the University of Cambridge. Can you guess what her favorite subject was? Chimpanzees!

Her discoveries during those years completely changed the way people think about primates. Before Goodall's work, people thought chimpanzees were herbivores. An herbivore is an animal that only eats plants. She discovered that chimps also eat meat, making them omnivores. An omnivore is an animal that eats both plants and meat.

---

More importantly, Goodall discovered that chimps were very intelligent. Being intelligent means being smart and able to learn new things. She watched them making and using tools! Before that, people thought humans were the only animals that made and used tools. Goodall saw chimps using blades of grass and sticks as tools. Chimps like to eat termites, which are insects like ants. To catch these tasty insects, a chimp would stick a blade of grass into a termite hole. The termites would crawl onto the grass. Then, the chimp would pull out the grass and eat all the termites.
Goodall gave names to all the chimps she studied. She learned that chimps show many of the same feelings as people. They can feel happy, sad, and angry. This behavior helped people understand that chimps are very special animals.

---

Goodall is more than a scientist. She is also an activist. An activist is someone who works hard to solve problems and change things in the world. Goodall works to protect chimpanzees and their homes in the wild. She teaches others about human damage to animal homes. This damage includes hunting and pollution. Pollution happens when harmful things get into the air, water, or land where animals live.
She loves working with young people and teaching them how to protect animals. She has written many books and has won many awards for her work. Even when she was 79 years old, she was still working to spread the message that animals need our protection!

option_1: to prove that chimps are better at using tools than humans
option_2: to demonstrate that chimps mostly prefer insects over other types of food

passage_text:
Jane Goodall
    
    
        Jane Goodall is a very famous primatologist. A primatologist is a scientist who studies a group of animals called primates. Primates are mammals that include humans, monkeys, gorillas, and chimpanzees. Jane Goodall has spent her whole life studying chimpanzees. She watches their behavior, which means how they act and what they do each day. Her discoveries have made her one of the best known scientists in the world.
Goodall was born in 1934 in London, England. When she was a little girl, her father gave her a toy chimpanzee. It looked so real that people who visited her house were afraid of it, but she loved it! This toy helped her dream about studying real chimpanzees someday.

---

When Goodall was 23 years old, she went to Africa. She began studying chimpanzees with a well-known scientist named Louis Leakey. After a year of working in Africa, Goodall went back to England. She studied at the University of Cambridge. Can you guess what her favorite subject was? Chimpanzees!
After finishing school, Goodall returned to Africa. She spent the next 45 years studying chimpanzees in the wild. Her discoveries during those years completely changed the way people think about primates. Before Goodall's work, people thought chimpanzees were herbivores. An herbivore is an animal that only eats plants. She discovered that chimps also eat meat, making them omnivores. An omnivore is an animal that eats both plants and meat.

---

More importantly, Goodall discovered that chimps were very intelligent. Being intelligent means being smart and able to learn new things. She watched them making and using tools! Before that, people thought humans were the only animals that made and used tools. Goodall saw chimps using blades of grass and sticks as tools. Chimps like to eat termites, which are insects like ants. To catch these tasty insects, a chimp would stick a blade of grass into a termite hole. The termites would crawl onto the grass. Then, the chimp would pull out the grass and eat all the termites.
Goodall gave names to all the chimps she studied. She learned that chimps show many of the same feelings as people. They can feel happy, sad, and angry. This behavior helped people understand that chimps are very special animals.

---

Goodall is more than a scientist. She is also an activist. An activist is someone who works hard to solve problems and change things in the world. Goodall works to protect chimpanzees and their homes in the wild. She teaches others about human damage to animal homes. This damage includes hunting and pollution. Pollution happens when harmful things get into the air, water, or land where animals live.
She loves working with young people and teaching them how to protect animals. She has written many books and has won many awards for her work. Even when she was 79 years old, she was still working to spread the message that animals need our protection!
question: Which two details from the passage are most important for understanding that Jane Goodall made significant contributions to science?
option_1: She studied at Cambridge, and she was born in London.
option_2: She loved her toy chimp, and she went to Africa at 23.
option_3: She discovered chimps are omnivores, and she saw them use tools.
option_4: She gave chimps names, and she worked with Louis Leakey.
option_1_explanation: Good try! These facts tell us about Jane's life, but not what she discovered. The story talks about her amazing findings, not where she was born or went to school.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but these show how Jane got interested in chimps, not what she found out. Look for what she discovered that changed how people think about chimps.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says her discoveries "completely changed the way people think about primates." These two findings made her famous in science.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Working with Louis and naming chimps are mentioned, but the story doesn't call these big science discoveries. Focus on what she found out about how chimps live.
differentiation_notes: Targets combination of two key discoveries across sections 2-3 - differs from reference which asks same question
homogeneity_check: all choices are pairs of biographical/scientific details
specificity_check: all are combinations of two facts from the passage
length_check: A=10 words, B=11 words, C=10 words, D=10 words - balanced within 9%
semantic_distance_check: distinct combinations: education+birth vs. toy+travel vs. discoveries vs. naming+colleague
single_correct_check: only C contains two details explicitly described as important discoveries
diversity_check: targets same discoveries as reference but asks which details show contributions vs. changed thinking - different framing

question: The passage describes Jane Goodall's life from childhood to age 79. Which statement best explains the main idea about her life's work?
option_1: She traveled between England and Africa many times.
option_2: She dedicated her entire life to understanding and protecting chimpanzees.
option_3: She became famous because of a toy her father gave her.
option_4: She preferred studying at Cambridge over working in Africa.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Jane did travel a lot, but that's not what the whole story is about. The story shows how everything she did was about studying chimps.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says she "spent her whole life studying chimpanzees." From her toy chimp to working at 79, everything was about chimps.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the toy just got her interested in chimps. Her fame came from all her amazing discoveries about how chimps really live.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story never says she liked one place better. She used both places to learn more about chimps.

option_1: Chimps can feel emotions, and they live in family groups.
option_2: Chimps are primates, and they are mammals.
option_3: Chimps eat meat instead of only plants, and they make tools instead of only humans making tools.

option_2_explanation: Not quite! The story already said chimps were primates and mammals at the beginning. These weren't new discoveries that surprised anyone.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says "people thought chimpanzees were herbivores" and that only humans made tools before Jane's discoveries. She proved both ideas wrong!

Before that, people thought humans were the only animals that made and used tools. Goodall saw chimps using blades of grass and sticks as tools. Chimps like to eat termites, which are insects like ants. To catch these tasty insects, a chimp would stick a blade of grass into a termite hole. The termites would crawl onto the grass. Then, the chimp would pull out the grass and eat all the termites.
Goodall gave names to all the chimps she studied. She learned that chimps show many of the same feelings as people. They can feel happy, sad, and angry. This behavior helped people understand that chimps are very special animals.

---

Goodall is more than a scientist. She is also an activist. An activist is someone who works hard to solve problems and change things in the world. Goodall works to protect chimpanzees and their homes in the wild. She teaches others about human damage to animal homes. This damage includes hunting and pollution. Pollution happens when harmful things get into the air, water, or land where animals live.
She loves working with young people and teaching them how to protect animals. She has written many books and has won many awards for her work. Even when she was 79 years old, she was still working to spread the message that animals need our protection!

option_1: It shows the next idea is more important, clarifying the main link.

passage_text:
Deep-Sea Fish
    
    
        Oceans are very deep bodies of water. People cannot go very deep into the ocean, even with special equipment. Divers use scuba gear to breathe underwater. This includes a tank of oxygen and other tools. But there is still a limit to how deep anyone can go.
The deeper you go, the more water pressure you feel. This happens because of the weight of all the water around you. You can feel this pressure when you swim to the bottom of a pool. If you stay on the pool floor for a few seconds, you will feel pressure in your ears. In the ocean, this pressure gets much stronger as you go deeper.

---

How deep are oceans? It depends on where you are in the world. Some parts are only a few yards deep. Other parts can be around 10,000 feet deep. The deepest part of the ocean is more than six miles down! The water pressure there is incredibly strong. It would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you at the same time. A person would be crushed to the size of an ant or smaller.
No land animals can survive the water pressure of the deep ocean. Most fish cannot either. However, there is lots of life down there! How do we know this? Scientists have created special underwater vehicles called submersibles that can go very deep. A submersible is different from a regular submarine. Some submersibles can carry one or two people. Others are controlled from the surface using remote controls.

---

With lights and cameras, a submersible can explore the deepest parts of the ocean. Scientists made the first submersible about 50 years ago. They have been discovering amazing fish ever since! Fish that live deep in the ocean are unlike any other creatures. They have very thick bodies to handle all that water pressure.
No sunlight reaches the bottom of the ocean, so it is completely dark down there. Many deep-sea fish actually glow! Lantern fish are the most common deep-sea fish. There are billions of them swimming in the deep ocean. The anglerfish is one of the strangest creatures on Earth. It has a huge mouth and scary teeth. It also has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.

---

Humans have only explored a tiny part of the deep seas. There are still many creatures waiting to be discovered. If you want to discover new ocean animals, you might want to become a marine biologist. A marine biologist is a scientist who studies ocean life and explores the mysteries of the deep sea.
question: Read the sentence from the passage. 'It would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you at the same time.' What is this sentence telling you?
option_1: There are many elephants living in the deep ocean.
option_2: Deep-sea fish are as big as elephants.
option_3: Scientists use elephants to explore the ocean.
option_4: The water pressure in the deep ocean is very strong.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says elephants can't live in deep water because "no land animals can survive." The elephant comparison just shows how strong the water pressure feels.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the elephant part isn't about fish size. The story says "water pressure there is incredibly strong" and compares it to elephants pressing down.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Scientists don't use real elephants - they use "submersibles" to explore. The elephant example just shows how strong the water pressure feels.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer because the story says "water pressure there is incredibly strong." The elephant comparison helps us understand how powerful that pressure is.

No sunlight reaches the bottom of the ocean, so it is completely dark down there. Many deep-sea fish actually glow! Lantern fish are the most common deep-sea fish. There are billions of them swimming in the deep ocean. The anglerfish is one of the strangest creatures on Earth. It has a huge mouth and scary teeth. It also has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.

---

Humans have only explored a tiny part of the deep seas. There are still many creatures waiting to be discovered. If you want to discover new ocean animals, you might want to become a marine biologist. A marine biologist is a scientist who studies ocean life and explores the mysteries of the deep sea.

option_1: To explain why ants cannot live in the ocean
option_2: To show that deep-sea fish are very small
option_3: To help readers understand how powerful the pressure is
option_4: To describe what scientists look for underwater

option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the ant comparison is about what would happen to people, not fish. The story says deep-sea fish have thick bodies to handle the pressure.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The author says a person would be "crushed to the size of an ant" to help us picture how incredibly strong the water pressure is down deep.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! This detail is about the scary water pressure, not about what scientists are looking for. The ant comparison shows how dangerous the deep ocean is.

passage_text:
Deep-Sea Fish
    
    
        Oceans are very deep bodies of water. People cannot go very deep into the ocean, even with special equipment. Divers use scuba gear to breathe underwater. This includes a tank of oxygen and other tools. But there is still a limit to how deep anyone can go.

---

The deepest part of the ocean is more than six miles down! The water pressure there is incredibly strong. It would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you at the same time. A person would be crushed to the size of an ant or smaller.
No land animals can survive the water pressure of the deep ocean. Most fish cannot either. However, there is lots of life down there! How do we know this? Others are controlled from the surface using remote controls.

---

---

passage_text:
Deep-Sea Fish
    
    
        Oceans are very deep bodies of water. People cannot go very deep into the ocean, even with special equipment. Divers use scuba gear to breathe underwater. This includes a tank of oxygen and other tools. But there is still a limit to how deep anyone can go.
The deeper you go, the more water pressure you feel. This happens because of the weight of all the water around you. You can feel this pressure when you swim to the bottom of a pool. If you stay on the pool floor for a few seconds, you will feel pressure in your ears. In the ocean, this pressure gets much stronger as you go deeper.

---

How deep are oceans? It depends on where you are in the world. Some parts are only a few yards deep. Other parts can be around 10,000 feet deep. The deepest part of the ocean is more than six miles down! The water pressure there is incredibly strong. It would feel like 3,300 elephants dropped on you at the same time. A person would be crushed to the size of an ant or smaller.
No land animals can survive the water pressure of the deep ocean. Most fish cannot either. However, there is lots of life down there! How do we know this? Scientists have created special underwater vehicles called submersibles that can go very deep. A submersible is different from a regular submarine. Some submersibles can carry one or two people. Others are controlled from the surface using remote controls.

---

With lights and cameras, a submersible can explore the deepest parts of the ocean. Scientists made the first submersible about 50 years ago. They have been discovering amazing fish ever since! Fish that live deep in the ocean are unlike any other creatures. They have very thick bodies to handle all that water pressure.
No sunlight reaches the bottom of the ocean, so it is completely dark down there. Many deep-sea fish actually glow! Lantern fish are the most common deep-sea fish. There are billions of them swimming in the deep ocean. The anglerfish is one of the strangest creatures on Earth. It has a huge mouth and scary teeth. It also has something like a built-in flashlight on its head to talk to other fish.

---

Humans have only explored a tiny part of the deep seas. There are still many creatures waiting to be discovered. If you want to discover new ocean animals, you might want to become a marine biologist. A marine biologist is a scientist who studies ocean life and explores the mysteries of the deep sea.
question: In paragraph 3, what does the phrase 'something like a built-in flashlight' describe?
option_1: The way lantern fish produce light
option_2: The cameras used on submersibles
option_3: The special feature on an anglerfish's head
option_4: The tool divers use to see underwater
option_1_explanation: Good try! The passage doesn't say lantern fish have a 'built-in flashlight.' It talks about a different fish with a light on its head.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The 'built-in flashlight' isn't about camera equipment. The passage is talking about a special body part that a fish has.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The passage says the anglerfish 'has something like a built-in flashlight on its head.' This describes the special light on the fish's head.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the 'built-in flashlight' isn't diver equipment. The passage is describing a special light that grows on a fish's body.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 figurative language about anglerfish feature - differs from reference which asks about 'crushed' meaning, focusing on different vocabulary and different literary device (metaphor vs verb meaning)

specificity_check: all identify specific light-related features or equipment

single_correct_check: only C correctly identifies what the phrase modifies in context

option_4_explanation: Not quite! Marine biologists are only mentioned at the very end as a job idea. The main story is about how scientists use submersibles to study the deep ocean where regular people can't go.

passage_text:
Tree Frogs
    
    
        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. This helps them breathe underwater. Later, they grow lungs so they can breathe air on land. Tree frogs are one kind of amphibian. They are different because they spend most of their time up in trees.
The American green tree frog lives in the southeastern United States. These frogs are very small. A typical tree frog is only about two inches long. But they can make a lot of noise when many of them get together. If you live in the southern United States near water and trees, you might hear their gentle chirps on summer nights.

---

American tree frogs can be lime green or yellow in color. Their most special feature is their long toes. Each toe has a suction cup at the end. These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb. They can even stick to windows! Tree frogs like to stay up in trees, so you will probably hear them before you see them. They only come down to lay their eggs. They are most likely to come to the ground after heavy rain, when everything is wet.
If you do see a tree frog, don't be scared! They are friendly animals. They are easy to catch too. If you catch one, it might sit on your hand or crawl on your back. You will probably only find them at night because they are nocturnal. This means they sleep during the day and are awake at night. They eat small bugs like crickets and moths.

---

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

passage_text:
Tree Frogs
    
    
        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. This helps them breathe underwater. Later, they grow lungs so they can breathe air on land. Tree frogs are one kind of amphibian. They are different because they spend most of their time up in trees.
The American green tree frog lives in the southeastern United States. These frogs are very small. A typical tree frog is only about two inches long. But they can make a lot of noise when many of them get together. If you live in the southern United States near water and trees, you might hear their gentle chirps on summer nights.

---

American tree frogs can be lime green or yellow in color. Their most special feature is their long toes. Each toe has a suction cup at the end. These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb. They can even stick to windows! Tree frogs like to stay up in trees, so you will probably hear them before you see them. They only come down to lay their eggs. They are most likely to come to the ground after heavy rain, when everything is wet.
If you do see a tree frog, don't be scared! They are friendly animals. They are easy to catch too. If you catch one, it might sit on your hand or crawl on your back. You will probably only find them at night because they are nocturnal. This means they sleep during the day and are awake at night. They eat small bugs like crickets and moths.

---

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

passage_text:
Tree Frogs
    
    
        Amphibians are special animals that live in two places. They spend part of their lives in water and part on land. When they are babies, they have gills like fish. This helps them breathe underwater. Later, they grow lungs so they can breathe air on land. Tree frogs are one kind of amphibian. They are different because they spend most of their time up in trees.
The American green tree frog lives in the southeastern United States. These frogs are very small. A typical tree frog is only about two inches long. But they can make a lot of noise when many of them get together. If you live in the southern United States near water and trees, you might hear their gentle chirps on summer nights.

---

American tree frogs can be lime green or yellow in color. Their most special feature is their long toes. Each toe has a suction cup at the end. These suction cups help tree frogs stick to anything they want to climb. They can even stick to windows! Tree frogs like to stay up in trees, so you will probably hear them before you see them. They only come down to lay their eggs. They are most likely to come to the ground after heavy rain, when everything is wet.
If you do see a tree frog, don't be scared! They are friendly animals. They are easy to catch too. If you catch one, it might sit on your hand or crawl on your back. You will probably only find them at night because they are nocturnal. This means they sleep during the day and are awake at night. They eat small bugs like crickets and moths.

---

Like other amphibians, American green tree frogs lay their eggs in or near water. Most of them like to put their eggs very close to water, but not right in it. Their favorite spot is on a tree branch that has fallen into a pond. Tree frogs have been around for a very long time. They lived on Earth even before dinosaurs! You can find different types of tree frogs in North America, South America, Europe, and Southeast Asia.
Most tree frogs like a warm, wet climate. If you live where tree frogs are found, you are lucky! In the summer, you can fall asleep listening to the sounds of many tree frogs singing together. It sounds like a beautiful orchestra of nature.

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: The author of this passage would most likely agree that
option_1: Komodo dragons should be respected from a distance.
option_2: All dragons are just make-believe creatures.
option_3: Only fairy tale dragons are truly dangerous.
option_4: People should try to pet Komodo dragons at zoos.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading that they "attacked people before." The author wants us to stay safe around these big reptiles.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story does talk about fairy tale dragons, but it also says Komodo dragons are real. The author thinks we should be careful around the real ones.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says real Komodo dragons "can be quite dangerous" too. The author warns us that both kinds of dragons can hurt people.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Even though zoos are safer, the story says these dragons have hurt people before. The author thinks we should look but not touch them.

passage_text:
The Komodo Dragon
    
    
        You have probably heard stories about dragons that breathe fire and fly around scaring people. A brave knight usually comes to save the day in these fairy tales. But real fire-breathing dragons never existed. However, there is one real dragon that lives today: the Komodo dragon. This dragon does not breathe fire or fly. It is just a very big reptile that can be quite dangerous. These animals have attacked people before, so you need to be very careful around them.
These special dragons get their name from the island of Komodo. This remote island is part of a country called Indonesia. You can also find Komodo dragons on four or five other islands nearby. But they are very rare animals. They like to live in hot, dry places. Each dragon digs a burrow in the ground that is two to three feet deep. Like most reptiles, they spend most of their time sleeping or resting in their burrow.

---

A Komodo dragon can grow as big as a crocodile or even bigger! They can weigh up to 150 pounds and grow over ten feet long from head to tail. The biggest one ever found weighed 370 pounds. That is as heavy as about six third-grade students put together!
Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!
question: According to paragraph 3, what do young Komodo dragons hunt that adult Komodo dragons do not?
option_1: They hunt water buffalo and deer in groups.
option_2: They hunt goats on the ground using their claws.
option_3: They hunt insects and birds by climbing trees.
option_4: They hunt dead animals they find lying around.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says adult dragons hunt big animals like water buffalo and deer. Young dragons are much smaller and hunt different things.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Adult dragons hunt goats on the ground with their claws. Young dragons do something different - they climb up high!
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says young dragons "eat insects, small mammals, and birds" and "climb trees to catch their prey." Adults don't climb trees.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says all dragons eat dead animals they find. This question asks what only young dragons hunt that's different.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 about young dragon hunting behavior - differs from reference by focusing on age-specific behavior differences rather than general location.
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about hunting behaviors of Komodo dragons
specificity_check: all choices describe specific prey and hunting methods
length_check: A=9 words, B=9 words, C=9 words, D=8 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: choices cover large prey in groups, goats on ground, insects in trees, dead animals - distinct hunting styles
single_correct_check: only C matches the specific description of young dragons climbing trees for insects and birds
diversity_check: targets paragraph 3 about age-specific hunting - completely different from reference about location and other variant about daily rest behavior

Like many reptiles, Komodo dragons cannot hear or see very well. But they have a very strong sense of smell. Here is something amazing: they do not use their nostril to smell things. Instead, they use their tongue! They stick out their tongue to smell food that is several miles away. This works best when the wind blows the smell toward them.

---

Komodo dragons are carnivores, which means they eat meat. Most of the time, they eat dead animals they find. But when they cannot find dead animals, they hunt for fresh food. They have very sharp claws and teeth. When they need to, they can move quite fast. They are the only lizards that can attack and eat animals bigger than themselves. They might hunt goats, deer, and even huge water buffalo!
Young Komodo dragons eat insects, small mammals, and birds. They climb trees to catch their prey. They will eat anything they can catch with their claws, as long as it has meat.

---

You never want a Komodo dragon to bite you or even lick you! Their saliva is full of dangerous germs that can make people very sick. The saliva in their mouth contains bacteria that can be deadly. The safest way to see a Komodo dragon is at a zoo. Only very brave scientists should get close to them in the wild!

option_1: to show how big and dangerous Komodo dragons are
option_2: to explain why Komodo dragons cannot fly
option_3: to describe what Komodo dragons look like
option_4: to help readers understand how heavy 370 pounds is

passage_text:
Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: According to the passage about beavers, what do beavers need to build their dams and lodges?
option_1: pelts from other animals
option_2: sharp teeth and flat tails
option_3: deep water from ponds and lakes
option_4: trees they gnaw down with their teeth
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says people wanted pelts to make coats, but that's not what beavers use to build. Beavers "gnaw down trees" to get wood for building.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but those are beaver body parts, not building materials! The story says beavers "gnaw down trees" and use the wood to build their homes.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Deep water is where beavers live, not what they build with. The story says they "gnaw down trees" to get wood for their dams.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading carefully. The story says beavers "gnaw down trees" and use that wood to build.

A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: According to the passage, what happens to the land after beavers build their dams?
option_1: The trees grow back stronger and healthier than before.
option_2: Other beaver families move in to share the territory.
option_3: The water rises and creates wetlands that help wildlife.
option_4: The rivers dry up and animals must find new homes.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say trees grow back stronger. It actually says beavers eat tree bark, so the trees get eaten instead.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but beavers don't share their homes. The story says they are "very territorial" and fight other beavers who try to move in.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The story says dams "make the water rise higher" and create wetlands. These wetlands help many animals like birds and fish live there.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Dams make water rise up, not dry up. The story says dams "make the water in rivers rise higher."

A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.

option_3: They don't want other beavers living in their space.
option_4: They mark their lodges with special signs to identify them.

passage_text:
Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.

Beavers
    
    
        Beavers are special mammals that do important work in nature. These animals have two main features that help them survive. First, they have long, sharp teeth that they use to gnaw down trees. To gnaw means to bite and chew on something hard. Second, they have flat, wide tails that help them swim fast in the water. Their tails also work like alarm bells. When a beaver sees danger, it slaps its tail hard on the water to warn other beavers.
Beavers live near ponds and lakes in North America, Europe, and Asia. Today, it is hard to find beavers in the wild. Long ago, people hunted so many beavers that they almost disappeared forever. This is called extinction. People wanted beaver pelts, which are the furry skins of animals. They used these pelts to make warm coats and hats. Even today, some people still hunt beavers or think they cause problems.

---

Beavers are the second biggest rodent in the world. A rodent is a type of animal with big front teeth, like mice, rats, and hamsters. People often say "busy as a beaver" because these animals work all the time. They spend most of their day in the water building things. Beavers are famous for making dams across rivers and streams. They build these dams to make the water deeper, which keeps them safe from bears and other animals that might hurt them.
When beavers sense danger, they can dive underwater and hold their breath for up to 15 minutes! They move slowly on land, but they swim very well. After building a dam, beavers make homes called lodges. These lodges are big piles of sticks and mud. Beavers use their strong teeth to gnaw down trees of all sizes. Then they eat the bark from the trees and use the leftover wood to build their dams and lodges.

---

One beaver family can change the land around them in big ways. Their dams make the water in rivers rise higher. This floods the land nearby and creates a swamp called a wetland. A wetland is a special place where land and water mix together. Many birds, fish, and insects need wetlands to live. However, people who live nearby might not like the flooding that beavers cause.
Beavers don't stay in one place very long. When they eat all the good tree bark in an area, they move down the river to start over. But the wetland they made often stays there long after they leave. Beavers are also very territorial. This means they don't want other beavers living in their space. They want to keep all the tasty tree bark for themselves! They will fight other beavers who try to move into their area. Beavers are truly amazing animals to watch and learn about.
question: According to the passage, what information helps readers understand where beavers build their homes?
option_1: Beavers create wetlands that flood the land near rivers and streams.
option_2: Beavers make lodges that are big piles of sticks and mud after building dams.
option_3: Beavers are famous for building dams to make water deeper and safer.
option_4: Beavers live near ponds and lakes on three different continents worldwide.
option_1_explanation: Good try! This talks about what happens around beaver homes, not where they build them. The story tells us where beavers actually make their homes.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story says beavers "make homes called lodges" that are "big piles of sticks and mud." This tells us exactly where and how they build their homes!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but this explains why beavers build dams, not where they make their homes. Dams and homes are different things beavers build.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! This tells us beavers live near water in different places, but doesn't say where they actually build their homes. Look for the word "lodges" in the story.

specificity_check: all provide specific information about beaver environment with similar detail
