passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: In Section 3, what does the word flexible mean?
option_1: able to bend
option_2: very strong
option_3: able to stick
option_4: very small
option_1_explanation: Great job! The story says flexible "can stretch and bend," so able to bend is right.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says flexible "can stretch and bend," not that it's strong.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but flexible means "can stretch and bend," not stick like glue does.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says flexible "can stretch and bend," not that it's small.

passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: How would the author most likely respond to someone who says hummingbirds are just ordinary birds?
option_1: agree that most birds have similar abilities
option_2: explain the many ways hummingbirds are unique
option_3: suggest studying larger birds instead of small ones
option_4: recommend reading different books about common birds
option_1_explanation: Good try! The author thinks hummingbirds are very different from other birds. The story says "No other birds can do this!" about their special flying tricks.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The author thinks hummingbirds are amazing, not ordinary. The story tells us "No other birds can do this!" and shares many cool facts about what makes them special.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The author loves writing about small hummingbirds and calls them "amazing little animals." The story shows these tiny birds are really interesting to learn about.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author wants us to learn about hummingbirds because they're special! The story shares lots of cool facts to show why these birds are worth reading about.
differentiation_notes: Targets how author would react to opposing viewpoint - differs from reference which asks directly about author's purpose
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential author responses or actions
specificity_check: all describe specific ways author might react
length_check: A: 6 words, B: 7 words, C: 7 words, D: 6 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each represents different type of response
single_correct_check: only B matches author's emphasis on unique features throughout
diversity_check: targets author's likely reaction - different from reference and variants 1-2

option_4: The babies start to grow inside the tiny nest.

option_3_explanation: Great job! The story says hummingbirds "lay two tiny eggs" and later "babies hatch." Between these steps, the eggs sit waiting to hatch!

passage_text:
Hummingbirds
    
    
        Birds live all around the world. They come in many sizes and colors. Some birds are very big, and some are very small. Hummingbirds are some of the smallest birds on Earth. The bee hummingbird is only two inches long. It weighs less than a penny!
Hummingbirds are amazing little animals. They can flap their wings up to 90 times in one second. That is so fast that their wings look like a blur. It is hard to see their wings because they move so quickly. These tiny birds can hover in the air like a helicopter. They can also fly backwards and upside-down. No other birds can do this!

---

Hummingbirds fly from flower to flower like busy bees. They use their long, pointy beaks to drink sweet nectar from flowers. Nectar is a sugary liquid that gives them lots of energy. Since they flap their wings so much, they need to eat a lot of food. A hummingbird will visit hundreds of flowers every day. It drinks more than its own weight in nectar! They also eat small insects they find on the flowers.
These birds love red flowers the most. People hang red feeders filled with sugary water to attract them. The feeders are dyed red because hummingbirds are drawn to this bright color. Many people enjoy watching these fast little birds at their feeders.

---

Many hummingbirds migrate to different places during the year. The ruby-throated hummingbird lives in the eastern United States during spring and summer. When autumn comes, it flies south to warmer places. This tiny bird makes an incredible journey. It flies 500 miles across the Gulf of Mexico without stopping! From there, it may continue south through Mexico to Costa Rica and other countries.
Hummingbird nests are very small. They are about half the size of a walnut shell. The birds make their nests using tiny pieces of moss and leaves. They use spider webs to hold everything together. The spider web works like glue because it is sticky. It is also flexible, which means it can stretch and bend.

---

A hummingbird lays two tiny eggs in its nest. When the babies hatch and start to grow, the spider web stretches to make the nest bigger. This helps keep the babies warm and safe as they get larger. The mother bird feeds her babies insects and sweet nectar. These amazing little birds are some of the most interesting creatures you can find!
question: Based on the passage, what must happen before the mother hummingbird can feed insects to her babies?
option_1: The spider web must stretch to make room for feeding.
option_2: The eggs must hatch so the babies are alive to eat.
option_3: The mother must collect moss and leaves for the nest.
option_4: The hummingbird must migrate back from Costa Rica.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says spider webs stretch as babies grow, but that's not what has to happen first. Before feeding can start, there need to be baby birds to feed!
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story says "When the babies hatch" and then the mother feeds them. First the eggs must hatch to make baby birds that need food!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story shows nest-building happens much earlier, before eggs are even laid. The babies need to hatch from eggs before mom can feed them.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says nesting and feeding happen in spring and summer, before the birds fly south. Migration comes after the babies are fed and grown up.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 3 prerequisite for feeding babies - differs from reference which asks about prerequisite for nest growth
homogeneity_check: all choices are prerequisite events or conditions
specificity_check: all describe specific actions that might precede feeding
length_check: A: 9 words, B: 10 words, C: 9 words, D: 8 words - balanced within 10%
semantic_distance_check: no synonyms - each represents different prerequisite step
single_correct_check: only B identifies the necessary condition (hatched babies) for feeding
diversity_check: targets different causal relationship (before feeding) vs reference (before growth) in Section 3

question: Why does the spider web need to be both sticky and flexible for the hummingbird nest?
option_1: Sticky holds materials together, and flexible allows the nest to stretch as babies grow.

option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't talk about sticking nests to trees or wind protection. The web holds materials together and stretches for growing babies.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't mention eggs rolling out or mom birds shaping nests. The web sticks materials together and stretches as babies grow bigger.

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: According to the text, what does Dr. Welbody say is needed to protect your brain?
option_1: soft organ inside your head
option_2: twenty-two bones that fit together
option_3: more than thirty small bones
option_4: bones shaped like a triangle
option_1_explanation: Good try! The brain is "a soft organ inside your head," but that's what needs protection. The story says your skull is made of "22 different bones that fit together" to protect your brain.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer in the story. The text says "Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together" to protect your brain.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's about your spine, not your skull! The story says your spine has "more than thirty small bones," but your skull has 22 bones.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Triangle-shaped bones aren't mentioned for protecting the brain. The story says your skull is made of "22 different bones that fit together."

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!
question: Why does Dr. Welbody include the Simon Says game at the end of his lesson? Give a reason for your answer from the text.
option_1: To help students practice and remember the bone names while making learning fun
option_2: To show students how their skeletal system works with their muscular system when they move
option_3: To demonstrate how bones like the ribs can expand when students take deep breaths
option_4: To test whether students were paying attention during her lesson about the three body systems
option_1_explanation: Great job! The story says "to practice these bone names" which shows the game helps students remember bones in a fun way.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says the game is "to practice these bone names," not to show how body systems work together.
option_3_explanation: Close! The ribs part is just one step in the game, but the story says the whole game is "to practice these bone names."
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says the game is "to practice these bone names," which means learning, not testing what they know.

passage_text:
The Skeletal System
    
    
        Hello! My name is Dr. Welbody. Some of you may remember me from when you were in first grade. I came to your school to teach you about your body. I told you to eat healthy food so you would grow big and strong. It looks like you listened! You have grown so much since then!
Today I am here to teach you more about your body and how it works. We will learn about three important systems. These are the skeletal system, the muscular system, and the nervous system. Each system has a special job to help your body work.

---

Let's start with the skeletal system. The skeletal system is made up of all the bones in your body. These bones give your body its shape. I have pictures on my computer to show you. You have more than 200 bones in your body! When I went to medical school, I had to learn the name of every single bone. That was very hard work!
Let's begin at the top with your skull. Doctors also call the skull the cranium. Your skull has a very important job. It protects your brain, which is a soft organ inside your head. You might think your skull is one big bone, but it's not! Your skull is actually made of 22 different bones that fit together.

---

Now rub the back of your neck. Can you feel the bone there? That is part of your spine. Your spine is made of more than thirty small bones stacked on top of each other. Each small bone is called a vertebra. All these bones together protect your spinal cord, which sends messages to your brain.
If you tap on your chest, you can feel your breastbone. The medical name for this bone is the sternum. If you tap to the left or right, you might feel your ribs. Your ribs protect important organs like your heart and lungs. The ribs look like a cage around these organs. Behind your ribs are two bones shaped like a triangle. These are your shoulder blade bones. The medical name for shoulder blade is scapula.

---

The pelvis is the group of bones at your hips. In your lower leg, you have two important bones. The tibia is the bigger bone, and the fibula is the smaller one next to it.
Now let's play Simon Says to practice these bone names! When you take a deep breath, watch how your rib cage can expand to make room for air. Your skeletal system works with your muscular system and nervous system to help you move and stay healthy. Are you ready to play?
Simon says, tap your skull! Simon says, now tap your cranium! Did I trick you? They are the same bone! Simon says, bend over and touch your tibia. Simon says, take a deep breath and feel your ribs expand. Now touch your scapula! Wait - I didn't say Simon says!

option_1: Dr. Welbody focuses on memorizing facts while textbooks encourage hands-on practice
option_2: Dr. Welbody combines explanations with physical activities that help students experience concepts
option_3: Dr. Welbody avoids technical vocabulary while textbooks use only medical terms
option_4: Dr. Welbody teaches less information than textbooks to make the content easier
option_1_explanation: Good try! Dr. Welbody actually has kids touch their bones and play games, not just memorize facts. She uses hands-on activities to help students learn.
option_2_explanation: Great job! Dr. Welbody says "rub the back of your neck" and uses activities with her explanations. She combines learning facts with feeling and moving.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but Dr. Welbody teaches both easy words (skull) and doctor words (cranium). She doesn't avoid the hard words - she explains them.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Dr. Welbody teaches lots of information - over 200 bones, skull facts, and spine details. She teaches the same amount but in a more active way.

question: If Dr. Welbody's computer pictures showed bones labeled only with medical terms like 'cranium' and 'sternum' without showing common names like 'skull' and 'breastbone,' how would this change the lesson for students?
option_1: Students would learn the information faster because they would only need to memorize one name per bone
option_2: Students would find the lesson more challenging because they could not connect new terms to familiar concepts
option_3: Students would remember the bones better because medical terms sound more professional and important
option_4: Students would become confused about which bones Dr. Welbody was teaching during the Simon Says game
option_1_explanation: Good try! Learning just one name doesn't make it faster when that name is really hard. Kids learn better when they know easy words first, then add the harder doctor words.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! Dr. Welbody says "Doctors also call the skull the cranium" to help kids connect new words to words they know. Without easy words like 'skull,' the hard doctor words would be too confusing.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but fancy words don't help kids remember better! Third graders remember things better when they can connect new words to words they already know and use.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The Simon Says game comes after the lesson, so kids would already be confused from the teaching part. The real problem happens when they first try to learn the bone names.

passage_text:
All About Bones
    
    
        Last time, we learned the names of some bones in the body. Today, let's learn more about bones! This is a human leg bone called the fibula. The fibula is one of the bones in your leg.

The outside part of a bone is very hard. It is made of the same stuff as a seashell you might find at the beach. This stuff is called calcium. Do you like milk? Milk and other dairy foods like cheese have lots of calcium in them. They are very good for your bones. One way to take care of your bones is to eat healthy foods with dairy products. Exercise is also great for your bones.

---

If you could look inside a bone, you would see something called bone marrow. Since you can't see inside this bone, I'll show you a picture. This picture shows bone marrow cells. You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: What does the word cope mean in section 4?
option_1: worry about
option_2: complain about
option_3: forget about
option_4: deal with
option_1_explanation: Good try! The boy wasn't worrying about the cast in the story. The text shows he wore it "for two months while the bones healed" and got better.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Cope doesn't mean complaining here. The story says he "had to cope with wearing the cast" and then got better, so he handled it well.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but cope doesn't mean forget about. He couldn't forget the cast since he "had to cope with wearing" it every day for two months.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You figured out that cope means "deal with" because the boy "had to cope with wearing the cast." He handled having the cast until his bones got better!

All About Bones
    
    
        Last time, we learned the names of some bones in the body. Today, let's learn more about bones! This is a human leg bone called the fibula. The fibula is one of the bones in your leg.

The outside part of a bone is very hard. It is made of the same stuff as a seashell you might find at the beach. This stuff is called calcium. Do you like milk? Milk and other dairy foods like cheese have lots of calcium in them. They are very good for your bones. One way to take care of your bones is to eat healthy foods with dairy products. Exercise is also great for your bones.

---

If you could look inside a bone, you would see something called bone marrow. Since you can't see inside this bone, I'll show you a picture. This picture shows bone marrow cells. You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: Based on paragraph 2, what does the word 'stuff' refer to when the author says bones are made of the same stuff as seashells?
option_1: a type of bone marrow
option_2: a mineral called calcium
option_3: red blood cells
option_4: dairy products like milk
option_1_explanation: Good try! Bone marrow is inside bones, but the story talks about the hard outside part. The story says "This stuff is called calcium."
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says "This stuff is called calcium." Calcium makes both bones and seashells hard and strong.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Red blood cells are made by bone marrow, but they don't make bones hard. The story says bones are made of calcium.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but dairy foods just have calcium in them. The "stuff" the story talks about is calcium itself, not the foods.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2's discussion of calcium composition - differs from reference which asks about 'cope' in paragraph 4. Uses 'Based on...' stem and requires understanding of pronoun reference rather than emotion-related vocabulary.
homogeneity_check: all choices are substances/materials (bone marrow, calcium, blood cells, dairy products)
specificity_check: all at concrete noun level naming specific materials
length_check: A=5 words, B=4 words, C=3 words, D=4 words - balanced within acceptable range
semantic_distance_check: no overlapping meanings - each represents distinct material concept
single_correct_check: only B is defensible based on explicit text statement 'This stuff is called calcium'
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 calcium explanation - completely different from reference's paragraph 4 emotional vocabulary question

question: According to the passage, what does 'set the bone' mean when describing what doctors do?
option_1: take x-ray pictures of the bone
option_2: put the bone pieces in the correct position
option_3: remove the cast from the healed bone
option_4: wait for the bone to grow back together
option_1_explanation: Good try! Taking x-rays happens before setting the bone. The story says doctors take pictures first to see if it's broken.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The passage says "put the bone pieces back in the right place." That's exactly what setting means!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but removing the cast comes much later. Setting the bone happens right after the doctor sees it's broken.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Waiting for healing comes after setting the bone. The story shows that setting is something the doctor does first.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4's medical procedure terminology - differs from reference which asks about emotional vocabulary 'cope'. Uses 'According to...' stem and focuses on technical/procedural language rather than emotional states.

question: What does the word 'tissue' mean in paragraph 3 when the author says 'The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard'?
option_1: special x-ray pictures
option_2: body material like muscles and skin
option_3: broken bone pieces
option_4: hard calcium structures
option_1_explanation: Good try! X-ray pictures help doctors see bones, but tissue means the actual body parts. The story talks about soft body material around bones, not pictures.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says tissue is "not as hard" as bones. Tissue means the soft body parts like muscles and skin around your bones.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but broken bone pieces aren't tissue. The story talks about soft tissue around healthy bones, not broken parts.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says tissue is "not as hard" as bones. Tissue is the soft stuff around bones, not the hard bone parts.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3's scientific terminology about body composition - differs from reference which asks about 'cope' (emotional vocabulary). Uses 'What does...mean' stem but focuses on anatomical/scientific language rather than everyday emotional terms.

question: In paragraph 2, what does the phrase 'work like little factories' tell you about bone marrow cells?
option_1: They are very small in size.
option_2: They can be seen with microscopes.
option_3: They produce something important.
option_4: They are found inside bones.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says factories are 'little,' but that's not what this phrase means. It's talking about what the cells DO, not how big they are.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The story mentions microscopes, but 'work like little factories' tells us about their job. Factories are places that make things!
option_3_explanation: You got it! The phrase means they 'make red blood cells' just like factories make things. Bone marrow cells are tiny makers inside your bones!
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story already told us they're inside bones. 'Work like little factories' is about their special job of making blood cells!
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 2's factory simile about bone marrow cell function - differs from reference which asks about the same simile but as an RI.3.1 question testing explicit text reference. This variant requires DOK 2 interpretation of what the metaphor emphasizes (production) rather than what it states (the cells make blood cells).
homogeneity_check: all choices are characteristics or functions of bone marrow cells
specificity_check: all at descriptive phrase level about cell properties
length_check: A=5 words, B=5 words, C=4 words, D=4 words - balanced within 10%

single_correct_check: only C is defensible as the emphasis of the factory metaphor based on context
diversity_check: targets paragraph 2 figurative language interpretation - different from all previous variants and from reference's paragraph 4 focus. Requires inferring metaphor's emphasis rather than explicit statement.

question: Someone might read this passage to
option_1: persuade others to drink milk.
option_2: enjoy a story about bones.

question: A reader would most likely use this passage to
option_1: understand how to treat broken bones at home.
option_2: discover information about the human skeleton system.
option_3: enjoy an entertaining story about visiting a doctor.
option_4: decide whether to drink more milk each day.

option_2_explanation: Great job! The story teaches us "All About Bones" with lots of facts. It explains what bones are made of, what's inside them, and how they grow.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but this isn't a fun story about visiting a doctor. It's a lesson that teaches facts about bones and how they work in your body.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story mentions milk is good for bones, but that's just one small part. The whole story is about teaching us many different bone facts.

question: Based on the whole passage, the author most likely believes that
option_1: children should avoid activities that might break bones.
option_2: bones are fascinating parts of the human body.
option_3: drinking milk is the only way to have strong bones.
option_4: x-ray technology is too complicated for most people.

option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story says milk helps bones, but also says "Exercise is also great for your bones." The author gives more than one way to keep bones healthy.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't really talk about x-ray technology being too hard. The author explains things in simple ways that kids can understand.

passage_text:
All About Bones
    
    
        Last time, we learned the names of some bones in the body. Today, let's learn more about bones! This is a human leg bone called the fibula. The fibula is one of the bones in your leg.

The outside part of a bone is very hard. It is made of the same stuff as a seashell you might find at the beach. This stuff is called calcium. Do you like milk? Milk and other dairy foods like cheese have lots of calcium in them. They are very good for your bones. One way to take care of your bones is to eat healthy foods with dairy products. Exercise is also great for your bones.

---

If you could look inside a bone, you would see something called bone marrow. Since you can't see inside this bone, I'll show you a picture. This picture shows bone marrow cells. You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: Why would someone choose to read this passage instead of a story about a child who broke their arm?
option_1: To learn general facts about how bones work in the body.
option_2: To find out what happened to one specific child.
option_3: To enjoy following a character through an adventure.
option_4: To feel emotions about a challenging experience.
option_1_explanation: Great job! This passage teaches us "about bones" with facts like how calcium makes them hard. Someone would read this to learn how bones really work.
option_2_explanation: Good try! This passage talks about all bones, not one child's story. It teaches facts like "bone marrow" instead of telling what happened to someone.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Adventures happen in stories with characters doing exciting things. This passage just teaches facts about bones and doesn't follow anyone around.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but this passage teaches facts, not feelings! It explains how bones work with "calcium" and marrow instead of making us feel sad or scared.
differentiation_notes: Targets reader purpose by contrasting text types (informational vs. narrative) - differs from reference's general purpose question and previous variants' author perspective focus. Uses 'Why would someone choose' stem to assess RI.3.6 by having students distinguish informational from narrative purposes.
homogeneity_check: all choices are reasons/purposes for reading a text
specificity_check: all at purpose statement level using infinitive phrases
length_check: A=10 words, B=8 words, C=7 words, D=6 words - within acceptable range for meaning clarity
semantic_distance_check: each represents distinct reading purpose: education, specific narrative, entertainment, emotion
single_correct_check: only A is defensible as this is informational text providing factual education, not narrative
diversity_check: targets text type distinction and reader purpose selection - different from all previous variants by requiring contrast between informational vs. narrative purposes

question: Read the sentence from the passage. 'They work like little factories.' What do you think this sentence is telling you?
option_1: Bone marrow cells make red blood cells.
option_2: Bone marrow cells can be seen with microscopes.
option_3: Bone marrow cells are found inside bones.
option_4: Bone marrow cells are very small in size.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found what bone marrow cells do. The story says "They make red blood cells," which is exactly what factories do - they make things!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story does mention microscopes, but that's not what "like little factories" means. Factories make things, and bone marrow cells make red blood cells.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but being inside bones isn't what makes them like factories. The story says they "make red blood cells" - that's the factory job they do!
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Being small doesn't make them like factories. The story says they "make red blood cells" - making things is what factories do!

option_1: The doctor should cut off the cast.

option_3: The patient should wait two months for healing.
option_4: The doctor should set the bone in the right place.

You may already know about cells. If you look at things with a strong microscope, you can see that many things are made of tiny cells. Your skin is made of cells. Your bones are made of cells too.

Here you can see some bone marrow cells. There are millions of cells like these inside your bones. The bone marrow cells have a very important job. They work like little factories. They make red blood cells. Then, the red blood cells carry oxygen all around your body.

---

As you get older and taller, your bones grow with you. Bones are very strong. They can hold up a lot of weight. But if we put too much pressure on them, or if the pressure comes from the wrong way, bones can break.
This next picture shows a broken bone. This is a special kind of picture called an x-ray. X-rays help us see inside your body. Your bones are hard, so they show up well in x-ray pictures. The soft tissue around your bones is not as hard. That is why doctors like x-rays. We can take pictures of the inside of your body. We can use x-rays to find out if any bones are broken.

---

Have any of you ever broken a bone? I fix lots of broken bones each year. First, I take x-rays to see if the bone is really broken. If the x-rays show that a bone is broken, then I set the bone. That means I put the bone pieces back in the right place. Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast.
One amazing thing about bones is that they can heal themselves. Once a broken bone has been set, it grows back just like it was before. Here's a boy I helped last summer. He broke one of the bones in his arm. I put the cast on to hold the bones in the right place so they would heal. He had to cope with wearing the cast for two months while the bones healed. Then, I cut the cast off for him. He's just fine now. His bone has healed and his arm is as good as new.
question: What happens right after the doctor sets a broken bone?
option_1: The doctor takes x-rays to see where the break is located.
option_2: The bone pieces grow back together on their own.
option_3: The doctor applies a cast to hold bones in position.
option_4: The patient waits two months for complete healing.
option_1_explanation: Good try! X-rays happen before the doctor sets the bone, not after. The story says doctors take x-rays first to see the break.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but bones don't grow back together right away. The story shows it takes two months for bones to heal completely.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says "Once the bones are in the right place, I put on a cast." The cast goes on right after setting the bone.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The two months of waiting happens while wearing the cast. The cast gets put on first, then comes the long wait.

Uses different sequence point and requires tracking multi-step procedure through cause-effect relationships.

specificity_check: all at procedural step level describing specific actions or processes

question: According to the passage, what must be true before a broken bone can begin healing properly?
option_1: The bone fragments must be positioned correctly by the doctor.
option_2: The patient must wait several weeks with limited movement.
option_3: The doctor must remove the cast from the injured area.
option_4: The bone must be photographed using x-ray technology.

option_3_explanation: Not quite! The cast comes OFF after the bone is all better. The story says the doctor cuts off the cast when "His bone has healed."
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but x-rays help the doctor see what's wrong, not help the bone heal. The story shows bones need to be put in the right place to heal.

passage_text:
The Muscular System
    
    
        Have you ever watched a movie where skeletons chase people around? I saw a funny cartoon like that recently. Some kids were trying to solve a mystery, but they had big problems. Every time they looked for clues, a skeleton would jump out of a grave and run after them!
Well, as a doctor, I need to tell you something important. That's not very realistic at all! Bones cannot move by themselves. In fact, bones don't go anywhere without help from muscles. When I bend my arm, I use my muscle power. I make the muscles in my arm tight, and then the muscles move my bones and the rest of my arm. When you kick a soccer ball, it works the same way. You make the muscles in your legs tight to move your leg bones.

---

Our bodies have many muscles working together. This is called the muscular system. There are about 650 muscles in the human body! That's a lot of muscles. About half of what you weigh comes from your muscles. Pretty amazing, right?
Muscles are very important to us for many reasons. Can you think of some ways we use muscles? Muscles help us run fast and jump high. They let us stand up from a chair and sit back down. We use muscles when we lift heavy things like books or toys. We also use them when we chew our dinner and when we smile at our friends. We even use muscles when we breathe air into our lungs.

---

Doctors put muscles into two main groups. The first group is called voluntary muscles. These are muscles that you can control and make move when you want them to. The second group is called involuntary muscles. These are muscles that you cannot control at all. Involuntary muscles work automatically without you even thinking about them.
The muscles that help you move your arms and legs are voluntary muscles. When you want to pick up a heavy box, you think about it first. Then you make the muscles in your arms tight so you can lift the box up. You can also control the muscles in your legs when you want to make your body run around the playground or jump over a puddle.

---

But the muscles in your heart are involuntary muscles. They keep your heart beating all day and all night, whether you are awake or fast asleep. You don't have to remember to think, "Time to beat again, heart!" These muscles work automatically without any help from you. There are also involuntary muscles in your stomach. Your stomach muscles keep working to digest your food without you having to remind them to do their important job.
question: According to the text about muscles, what helps you lift a heavy box?
option_1: muscles that work automatically
option_2: muscles in your stomach
option_3: voluntary muscles in your arms
option_4: involuntary muscles in your heart
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says automatic muscles work by themselves, but lifting a box needs muscles you control. The story explains that "muscles that help you move your arms" are the ones you choose to use.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but stomach muscles work automatically without you controlling them. The story says "muscles that help you move your arms and legs" are the ones you control for lifting things.
option_3_explanation: Great job! You found the right connection between arm movement and voluntary muscles. The story says "muscles that help you move your arms and legs are voluntary" muscles.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Heart muscles work automatically, so you can't choose to use them for lifting. The story explains that "muscles that help you move your arms" are voluntary muscles you control.

The Muscular System
    
    
        Have you ever watched a movie where skeletons chase people around? I saw a funny cartoon like that recently. Some kids were trying to solve a mystery, but they had big problems. Every time they looked for clues, a skeleton would jump out of a grave and run after them!
Well, as a doctor, I need to tell you something important. That's not very realistic at all! Bones cannot move by themselves. In fact, bones don't go anywhere without help from muscles. When I bend my arm, I use my muscle power. I make the muscles in my arm tight, and then the muscles move my bones and the rest of my arm. When you kick a soccer ball, it works the same way. You make the muscles in your legs tight to move your leg bones.

---

Our bodies have many muscles working together. This is called the muscular system. There are about 650 muscles in the human body! That's a lot of muscles. About half of what you weigh comes from your muscles. Pretty amazing, right?
Muscles are very important to us for many reasons. Can you think of some ways we use muscles? Muscles help us run fast and jump high. They let us stand up from a chair and sit back down. We use muscles when we lift heavy things like books or toys. We also use them when we chew our dinner and when we smile at our friends. We even use muscles when we breathe air into our lungs.

---

Doctors put muscles into two main groups. The first group is called voluntary muscles. These are muscles that you can control and make move when you want them to. The second group is called involuntary muscles. These are muscles that you cannot control at all. Involuntary muscles work automatically without you even thinking about them.
The muscles that help you move your arms and legs are voluntary muscles. When you want to pick up a heavy box, you think about it first. Then you make the muscles in your arms tight so you can lift the box up. You can also control the muscles in your legs when you want to make your body run around the playground or jump over a puddle.

---

But the muscles in your heart are involuntary muscles. They keep your heart beating all day and all night, whether you are awake or fast asleep. You don't have to remember to think, "Time to beat again, heart!" These muscles work automatically without any help from you. There are also involuntary muscles in your stomach. Your stomach muscles keep working to digest your food without you having to remind them to do their important job.
question: Which detail from paragraph 3 best shows the difference between voluntary and involuntary muscles?
option_1: Voluntary muscles help you move your arms and legs.
option_2: Involuntary muscles work automatically without you thinking about them.
option_3: You can control voluntary muscles and make them move when you want.
option_4: Doctors put muscles into two main groups based on control.
option_1_explanation: Good try! This only tells about voluntary muscles, not both types. The question asks what shows the difference between them.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but this only explains involuntary muscles. You need a detail that talks about both muscle types together.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! This just describes voluntary muscles. Look for something that mentions how doctors separate the two types.
option_4_explanation: Great job! The passage says doctors put muscles "into two main groups." This shows they split muscles based on control!
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 3 classification system distinguishing both muscle types - differs from reference which focuses only on voluntary muscles in one specific action
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about muscle types and their characteristics
specificity_check: all provide specific information from paragraph 3
length_check: A=9 words, B=8 words, C=11 words, D=10 words - within 10% range
semantic_distance_check: choices focus on different aspects (voluntary only, involuntary only, voluntary control, classification system)
single_correct_check: only D addresses the distinguishing system for both types
diversity_check: targets paragraph 3 classification system - different from reference about voluntary muscle use in lifting

question: If a person could only use involuntary muscles, which of these would still happen automatically?
option_1: Their heart would keep beating.
option_2: They could run around the playground.
option_3: They could pick up a heavy box.
option_4: They could jump over a puddle.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that involuntary muscles work "automatically" without us controlling them. The heart keeps beating on its own!
option_2_explanation: Good try! Running needs voluntary muscles that you control with your thoughts. Involuntary muscles work automatically without thinking.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but picking up boxes uses arm muscles you control. The story says involuntary muscles work automatically like the heart beating.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Jumping uses leg muscles you control on purpose. Involuntary muscles work by themselves without you thinking about it.

question: If a person's voluntary muscles stopped working but their involuntary muscles continued, what would the person still be able to do?
option_1: Their stomach would continue digesting food.
option_2: They could kick a soccer ball with their legs.
option_3: They could smile at their friends.
option_4: They could stand up from a chair.
option_1_explanation: Great job! The story says stomach muscles "keep working to digest your food" without you controlling them. These automatic muscles would still work even if your control muscles stopped.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says you "make the muscles in your legs tight" to kick a ball. These are muscles you control, so they wouldn't work anymore.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story says "we use muscles when we smile at our friends." Smiling uses muscles you control, so you couldn't smile anymore.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says muscles "let us stand up from a chair." Standing uses muscles you control, so this wouldn't work anymore.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4 about involuntary stomach muscles continuing automatically - differs from reference which asks about involuntary heart muscles

question: Based on information in paragraphs 3 and 4, what can you conclude about the relationship between thinking and muscle control?
option_1: All muscles require you to think about them before they can move.
option_2: Some muscles move when you think about moving them, while others move without thought.
option_3: Thinking about your muscles makes them work faster and more efficiently.
option_4: Only doctors can control muscles by thinking about them carefully.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says some muscles "work automatically without you even thinking about them." Not all muscles need you to think first.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story shows voluntary muscles "you can control" and involuntary muscles that "work automatically without thinking." Some need thought, others don't!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't talk about muscles working faster when you think. It just explains which muscles you can control and which work by themselves.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say only doctors can control muscles. The doctor is teaching us that everyone can control some muscles by thinking about them.

question: What evidence from the passage supports the conclusion that humans depend on involuntary muscles for survival?
option_1: Involuntary muscles keep the heart beating day and night to circulate blood.
option_2: There are about 650 muscles in the human body working together.
option_3: Voluntary muscles allow people to run fast and jump high during exercise.
option_4: Muscles make up about half of a person's total body weight.
option_1_explanation: Exactly! The story says heart muscles "keep your heart beating all day and all night." Since your heart must beat to keep you alive, this shows we need involuntary muscles to survive.
option_2_explanation: Good try! This tells us how many muscles we have total, but it doesn't explain why involuntary muscles help us survive. The story talks about what the heart muscle does automatically.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Running and jumping use voluntary muscles that you control on purpose. The question asks about involuntary muscles that work automatically to keep you alive.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but this is about how heavy all muscles are together. It doesn't tell us why involuntary muscles are needed for survival or what important jobs they do automatically.
differentiation_notes: Requires evaluating evidence for survival dependence on involuntary muscles - differs from reference which asks about identifying single outcome

single_correct_check: only A connects involuntary muscle function to survival necessity

question: The author of this passage would most likely agree that
option_1: Muscles are necessary for all body movement.
option_2: Only doctors understand how muscles work.
option_3: People can control all of their muscles.
option_4: Skeletons in movies show how bones really work.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea that "bones cannot move by themselves" without muscles. The story shows muscles help us do everything from running to smiling!
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story has a doctor talking, but it never says only doctors know about muscles. The main point is that muscles are needed for all movement.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story mentions some muscles you can control and some you can't. The big idea is that muscles are needed to move our bodies.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says movie skeletons are "not very realistic" because bones need muscles to move. Muscles make all body movement happen.

question: The author begins the passage with a story about a cartoon with skeletons. Why is this an effective way to introduce the topic of muscles?
option_1: It makes the passage more entertaining so children will want to keep reading about science.
option_2: It presents a common misconception that the author can correct to teach how bones and muscles work together.
option_3: It shows that the author enjoys watching cartoons and movies with children.
option_4: It proves that skeletons in movies are scientifically accurate representations of the human body.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story is fun, but that's not the main reason the author used it. The author wanted to fix a wrong idea about how bones move.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! The author shows the wrong idea that bones can move alone, then says "That's not very realistic at all!" This helps teach that muscles move bones.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author didn't tell the story just to share what they like watching. The story has a special teaching purpose about bones and muscles.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The author says the cartoon is "not very realistic" because real skeletons can't move by themselves. The movie shows the wrong thing!
differentiation_notes: Analyzes author's rhetorical strategy using opening anecdote - differs from reference which asks what the example teaches about bones and muscles
homogeneity_check: all choices explain purposes for including the cartoon example
specificity_check: all propose specific reasons for the author's choice

semantic_distance_check: choices cover different purposes (entertainment, teaching via correction, personal sharing, proving accuracy)
single_correct_check: only B identifies the pedagogical strategy of correcting misconceptions
diversity_check: targets rhetorical effectiveness of opening strategy - different from reference about what example teaches

passage_text:
The Muscular System
    
    
        Have you ever watched a movie where skeletons chase people around? I saw a funny cartoon like that recently. Some kids were trying to solve a mystery, but they had big problems. Every time they looked for clues, a skeleton would jump out of a grave and run after them!
Well, as a doctor, I need to tell you something important. That's not very realistic at all! Bones cannot move by themselves. In fact, bones don't go anywhere without help from muscles. When I bend my arm, I use my muscle power. I make the muscles in my arm tight, and then the muscles move my bones and the rest of my arm. When you kick a soccer ball, it works the same way. You make the muscles in your legs tight to move your leg bones.

---

Our bodies have many muscles working together. This is called the muscular system. There are about 650 muscles in the human body! That's a lot of muscles. About half of what you weigh comes from your muscles. Pretty amazing, right?
Muscles are very important to us for many reasons. Can you think of some ways we use muscles? Muscles help us run fast and jump high. They let us stand up from a chair and sit back down. We use muscles when we lift heavy things like books or toys. We also use them when we chew our dinner and when we smile at our friends. We even use muscles when we breathe air into our lungs.

---

Doctors put muscles into two main groups. The first group is called voluntary muscles. These are muscles that you can control and make move when you want them to. The second group is called involuntary muscles. These are muscles that you cannot control at all. Involuntary muscles work automatically without you even thinking about them.
The muscles that help you move your arms and legs are voluntary muscles. When you want to pick up a heavy box, you think about it first. Then you make the muscles in your arms tight so you can lift the box up. You can also control the muscles in your legs when you want to make your body run around the playground or jump over a puddle.

---

But the muscles in your heart are involuntary muscles. They keep your heart beating all day and all night, whether you are awake or fast asleep. You don't have to remember to think, "Time to beat again, heart!" These muscles work automatically without any help from you. There are also involuntary muscles in your stomach. Your stomach muscles keep working to digest your food without you having to remind them to do their important job.
question: Based on the author's explanation in paragraph 1, what important scientific principle is the author teaching by contrasting the cartoon with reality?
option_1: Bones are stronger than muscles and can move by themselves.
option_2: Cartoons are always accurate representations of how the body works.
option_3: Multiple body systems must work together to produce movement.
option_4: Watching movies is a good way to learn about human anatomy.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says the opposite - that "bones cannot move by themselves." Bones need muscles to help them move.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The author says the cartoon is "not very realistic at all." The story shows that cartoons don't always show how our bodies really work.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The author explains that "bones don't go anywhere without help from muscles." The story teaches that bones and muscles must work together to move.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author uses the movie to show what's wrong, not what's right. The doctor corrects what the cartoon got wrong about how bodies move.
differentiation_notes: Requires identifying underlying scientific principle from paragraph 1 contrast - differs from reference which asks how example helps with main idea
homogeneity_check: all choices are scientific principles or claims about learning
specificity_check: all state general principles about bodies, accuracy, or learning
length_check: A=10 words, B=10 words, C=9 words, D=10 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: choices present distinct principles (bone independence, cartoon accuracy, system interaction, movie education)
single_correct_check: only C identifies the correct principle of system interdependence
diversity_check: targets underlying scientific principle from paragraph 1 - different from reference about helping readers understand

option_3_explanation: Good try, but the story doesn't compare how hard different muscles work. It's about which muscles work automatically versus which ones you control.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author says stomach muscles are involuntary. That means you CAN'T control them - they work automatically.

question: PART B: Based on the author's approach throughout the entire passage, what can you conclude about how the author wants readers to think about information they see in movies or cartoons?
option_1: Readers should use scientific knowledge to decide whether movie scenes could happen in real life
option_2: Readers should avoid watching movies with skeletons in them because they might have bad dreams
option_3: Readers should always believe what they see in movies because they are made by experts
option_4: Readers should only watch movies that have been approved by doctors and scientists
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that the author wants us to use science facts to check if movies are real. The text says "bones cannot move by themselves" to show the movie wasn't realistic.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The author doesn't say to avoid scary movies. The story shows us how to use science facts to figure out if movie scenes could really happen.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The author says the skeleton movie is "not very realistic" even though experts made it. We should use science knowledge to decide what's real.
option_4_explanation: Close! The author never says doctors must approve movies. The story teaches us to use science facts to figure out if movie scenes are realistic.

The Muscular System
    
    
        Have you ever watched a movie where skeletons chase people around? I saw a funny cartoon like that recently. Some kids were trying to solve a mystery, but they had big problems. Every time they looked for clues, a skeleton would jump out of a grave and run after them!
Well, as a doctor, I need to tell you something important. That's not very realistic at all! Bones cannot move by themselves. In fact, bones don't go anywhere without help from muscles. When I bend my arm, I use my muscle power. I make the muscles in my arm tight, and then the muscles move my bones and the rest of my arm. When you kick a soccer ball, it works the same way. You make the muscles in your legs tight to move your leg bones.

---

Our bodies have many muscles working together. This is called the muscular system. There are about 650 muscles in the human body! That's a lot of muscles. About half of what you weigh comes from your muscles. Pretty amazing, right?
Muscles are very important to us for many reasons. Can you think of some ways we use muscles? Muscles help us run fast and jump high. They let us stand up from a chair and sit back down. We use muscles when we lift heavy things like books or toys. We also use them when we chew our dinner and when we smile at our friends. We even use muscles when we breathe air into our lungs.

---

Doctors put muscles into two main groups. The first group is called voluntary muscles. These are muscles that you can control and make move when you want them to. The second group is called involuntary muscles. These are muscles that you cannot control at all. Involuntary muscles work automatically without you even thinking about them.
The muscles that help you move your arms and legs are voluntary muscles. When you want to pick up a heavy box, you think about it first. Then you make the muscles in your arms tight so you can lift the box up. You can also control the muscles in your legs when you want to make your body run around the playground or jump over a puddle.

---

But the muscles in your heart are involuntary muscles. They keep your heart beating all day and all night, whether you are awake or fast asleep. You don't have to remember to think, "Time to beat again, heart!" These muscles work automatically without any help from you. There are also involuntary muscles in your stomach. Your stomach muscles keep working to digest your food without you having to remind them to do their important job.
question: The author identifies as a doctor in paragraph 1. Why is this detail important to the passage's purpose?
option_1: It explains why the author enjoys watching cartoons with children.
option_2: It establishes the author's credibility to correct misconceptions about how the body works.
option_3: It shows that only doctors are allowed to write passages about the muscular system.
option_4: It proves that the author has stronger muscles than people in other professions.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The author talks about watching cartoons, but being a doctor isn't about liking movies. The doctor part helps us trust what they teach about bodies.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! The author says "as a doctor, I need to tell you something important" to show they know about bodies. This makes us believe their teaching about muscles and bones.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Anyone can write about muscles, not just doctors. The author mentions being a doctor to help us trust what they're teaching.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story never talks about the author's muscles being strong. Being a doctor means knowing about bodies, not having big muscles.

option_2: Voluntary muscles in different body parts can be controlled for different purposes.
option_3: Voluntary muscles require more conscious thought than involuntary muscles need.
option_4: Voluntary muscles work better during exercise than during everyday activities.

option_2_explanation: You got it! The author shows you can control arm muscles to "pick up a heavy box" and leg muscles to run. Voluntary muscles can be controlled everywhere in your body!

passage_text:
Joints and Muscles
Do you know what we call the place where two bones come together? It's called a joint. You have lots of joints in your body. Your elbow is a joint. So is your shoulder and your knee.Many joints are soft because of cartilage. Cartilage is a special kind of connective tissue. It is not as hard as bone, but it is stiffer than muscle. It is also flexible, which means it can bend. Do you remember learning about vertebrae? Those are the bones in your back. Well, we have cartilage between each of the thirty bones in our back. The cartilage works like a soft cushion. It keeps the bones from hitting each other.

---

You also have cartilage in your ears. Try this! Grab the top of your ear and bend it down a little. Now let it go. Do you feel how your ear snaps back? That's the cartilage working!Some very important tissues are found at your joints. A ligament is a kind of tissue that connects one bone to another bone. Most of your joints have ligaments. You have ligaments in your knee, neck, and wrists. For example, ligaments connect your thigh bone to the bones in your lower leg.

---

Ligaments connect bones to other bones. But tendons connect muscles to bones. Remember how the muscle system and bone system work together? Well, it's the tendons that link these two systems. The tendons connect muscles to bones and help you move. One of the most famous tendons in the body is called the Achilles tendon. Do you know where the Achilles tendon is?
That's right! The Achilles tendon is in the back of your leg, right above your heel. It connects your heel bone to the muscles in your lower leg. This is a very important tendon that you use when you walk or run.

---

Do you know why this tendon is called the Achilles tendon? Let me tell you the story!
When Achilles was a baby, his mother wanted to make sure he would never die. She heard that a person dipped in the River Styx could not be hurt by arrows or spears. She took her son and dipped him in the river. Then she felt better. She believed her son was invulnerable. This means nothing could harm him.
But there was one problem. When she dipped Achilles in the river, she held him by his heel. So his heel never got wet in the special river. Many years later, during the Trojan War, a Trojan warrior shot an arrow at Achilles. The arrow hit right above his heelthe very spot that had not been dipped in the River Styx. Achilles died from his wound. Now you know why the Achilles tendon is named for Achilles. This tendon was the one spot where the mighty warrior could be hurt.
question: What is Section 3 mostly about?
option_1: what tendons do in your body
option_2: when people use their tendons the most
option_3: where the Achilles tendon is located
option_4: how to care for sore tendons
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea about what tendons do. The text says "tendons connect muscles to bones" and explains their job in your body.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story mentions walking and running as examples, but it's really about what tendons do. The main idea is how "tendons connect muscles to bones."
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the Achilles tendon location is just one example. The whole section explains what tendons do - they "connect muscles to bones" to help you move.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story never talks about caring for sore tendons. It explains what tendons do - "connect muscles to bones and help you move."
