passage_text:
Androcles and the Lion
    
    
        Long ago in Rome, there was a slave named Androcles. He ran away from his master because he was treated badly. One night, Androcles found a cave in the mountains. He went inside the dark cave to hide and fell asleep on the cold ground.
In the middle of the night, a loud roaring sound woke him up. Androcles looked around in the darkness and saw something that scared him. A huge lion was coming into the cave! This was the lion's home. Androcles moved back against the cave wall. He thought the lion would kill him.
But then Androcles saw that something was wrong with the lion. The big cat was limping and roaring because it was hurt. The lion lay down and lifted up its front paw. It kept licking the paw over and over.

---

Androcles felt sorry for the lion. He decided to crouch down next to the hurt animal. The lion looked at him with sad eyes, like it was asking for help. Androcles looked at the paw and saw a big thorn stuck deep inside it. Very carefully, he reached out and pulled the thorn out of the lion's paw.
The lion purred and looked at Androcles with kind eyes. From that day on, they became the best of friends. Androcles learned to befriend the wild animal. They lived together in the cave for many months. They shared food and kept each other warm at night. The lion protected Androcles, and Androcles took care of the lion.

---

One day, Roman soldiers found Androcles hiding in the cave. The law said that runaway slaves must be punished. The soldiers captured Androcles and took him back to Rome. They put him in jail and gave him only water and old bread to eat.
After ten days, the guards told Androcles he would have to fight in the Colosseum. This was a huge building where Romans watched fights for fun. Runaway slaves were often forced to fight vicious wild animals or strong gladiators. Most slaves died in these fights. Androcles knew he would probably die, but he was brave.

---

When Androcles walked into the arena, thousands of Romans cheered loudly. They wanted to see a good fight. Then the guards let a lion into the arena. The crowd cheered even more because they thought the lion would kill Androcles.
But something amazing happened. This was the same lion that Androcles had helped! The lion ran to Androcles and began licking his face like a friendly dog. Androcles hugged his old friend and rubbed his belly. The crowd had never seen anything like this before.
"Free the slave!" people began to shout. "Free the lion too!" The emperor was watching from his special seat. He held up his hand with his thumb pointing up. This meant that Androcles and the lion had pleased him. They would both be set free! Androcles and his lion friend lived happily together for the rest of their lives.
question: Based on the text, which word best describes the lion when Androcles first saw it in the cave?
option_1: aggressive
option_2: suffering
option_3: playful
option_4: peaceful
option_1_explanation: Good try! The lion wasn't trying to attack Androcles. The story says it was "limping and roaring because it was hurt" and had "sad eyes."
option_2_explanation: You got it! The lion was "limping and roaring because it was hurt." It had a big thorn in its paw that made it suffer.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the lion wasn't playing around. It was "roaring" and "limping" because something was wrong with its paw.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! A peaceful animal wouldn't be "roaring" loudly. The lion was upset because it had a painful thorn stuck in its paw.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraphs 2-3 describing lion's condition - differs from reference about arena. This variant analyzes character state during cave encounter using specific text evidence.
homogeneity_check: all choices are emotional or physical states
specificity_check: all single-word descriptors of condition
length_check: A=1 word, B=1 word, C=1 word, D=1 word - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: choices cover hostility, pain, energy, calm - all distinct
single_correct_check: only B matches multiple text details about pain and injury
diversity_check: focuses on lion's physical/emotional state in cave - different from reference and variant 1

"Free the slave!" people began to shout. "Free the lion too!" The emperor was watching from his special seat. He held up his hand with his thumb pointing up. This meant that Androcles and the lion had pleased him. They would both be set free! Androcles and his lion friend lived happily together for the rest of their lives.
question: What lesson does the ending teach about the results of Androcles' choice to help the lion instead of running away?
option_1: Staying calm in scary situations always leads to freedom
option_2: Compassionate choices can bring unexpected future benefits
option_3: Wild animals remember faces better than people expect
option_4: Crowds have more power than rulers in making decisions
option_1_explanation: Good try! Androcles did stay calm, but he still got caught by soldiers. The story shows that helping the lion brought him a special reward later.
option_2_explanation: You got it! When Androcles helped the lion, he had no idea it would save his life later. The story teaches that being kind brings good things you don't expect.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the lesson isn't about how lions remember people. The story shows that when you help others, good things come back to you in surprising ways.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story isn't really about crowds having power. It's about how Androcles' kind choice to help the lion came back to help him later.
